title: Basic Clinical Embryology
requirements: For students in MSc Reproductive Medicine and Clinical Embryology
description: The aim of this module is to provide basic knowledge on human embryology from fertilization through birth. It includes:1. The mammalian reproductive system2. Gametogenesis3. Fertilisation and Early embryogenesis4. Embryonic Development of special systems5. Congenital malformations

title: Advanced Clinical Embryology
requirements: For students in MSc Reproductive Medicine and Clinical Embryology
description: This course allows students to have a highly advanced theoretical and practical understanding of human embryology. It helps student to understand more the applied aspects of clinical embryology. And, it help students to have a comprehensive overview of all aspects of the ART Laboratory, including the set-up and running of the laboratory, specific procedures, and quality control to ensure the highest possible success rates in an IVF program
outcome: The students are expected to understand the IVF Laboratory in the aspect of environment, equipment, work flow, staff and common regulations. In addition, they should acquire the knowledge on: a. Clinical Embryology Laboratory Routing Procedures; b. Cryo-preservation; c. Preimplantation Genetic Testing; d. Other technologies and procedures used by IVF lab; e. Establishing and maintaining an IVF Laboratory; f. Trouble shooting; and g. Future development.

description: This course provides a knowledge set appropriate for the broad range of health care professionals involved in the treatment of the infertile male, provide training in the assessement of parameters of male reproductive function, and assist professionals in identifying strategies for the treatment of male infertility. title: Clinical Issues and Controversies in ART
requirements: For students in MSc Reproductive Medicine and Clinical Embryology
description: In this course, the latest opinion and controversies in ART field (including both clinical part and lab part) will be reviewed and discussed.It includes the latest opinion and controversies in:1. ART diagnosis2. ART treatment3. ART technology4. The latest guidelines and opinions in the ART world5. The latest regulation and law in the ART world6. The latest opinion regarding ART Ethics Assessment: Debate
outcome: The students are expected to have critical thinking on the controversies and ethics issues over ART. They include:a. Embryo culture;b. Embryo selection;c. Embryo transfer;d. Assisted hatching;e. best development stage for embryo biopsy;f. Freezing; and g. Surgical sperm retrieval.

title: Genetics in Reproductive Medicine
requirements: For students in MSc Reproductive Medicine and Clinical Embryology
description: Reproductive genetics is an increasing part of the assisted reproductive technology (ART) practice. Daily, ART centers use genetic information when couples undergo ethnicity screening, when donors are screened and chosen for recipient couples, to determine the cause of infertility or recurrent pregnancy loss, and when utilizing preimplantation genetic screening (PGS) and preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD). However, the application of genetic information and genetic testing is often limited due to lack of knowledge by the medical providers in the ART practice. This course serves to provide basic to complex genetic information to help such practices start to fill this education gap and competently apply genetic information to improve patient care. It includes:1. Both basic genetics education and review of real time application. 2. The faculty will address current knowledge of the genetic causes of infertility 3. The latest research on and testing for infertility treatment and diagnosis4. The gamete donor and gestation carrier screening5. The PGD in clinical application6. The latest information about PGS7. The latest technology and its applications
outcome: At the conclusion of the course, students should be able to:1. explain genetic inheritance pattern, risk assessment and ethnicity screening;2. describe genetic and chromosomal causes of male and female infertility and infertility test options;3. define genetic and chromosomal test options for recurrent pregnancy-loss patients;4. outline donor carrier screening guidelines and their application to current practice;5. evaluate the value of high throughout carrier screening in the ART setting and review current test techniques and applications of PGD.
syllabus: Introduction: Get to know reproductive genetics Basic genetics and medical genetics Human reproduction and Epigenetics Human reproduction and Reproductive geneticsTechnology development in genetic testing Noninvasive prenatal testing (NIPT) Single molecule sequencing and its applications PGD and PGS technologies Mosaicism in preimplantation human embryos Mitochondrial DNA and mtDNA copy number and testing Clinical practices in reproductive genetics and case studies
